content: The Act titled "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015" includes sections on short title, findings, prospective reporting system, protection of dependent privacy, electronic statements, GAO studies, and eligibility verification process for ACA subsidies. The Act titled "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015" includes sections on findings, prospective reporting system, protection of dependent privacy, electronic statements, GAO studies, and eligibility verification process for ACA subsidies. Congress finds the need to minimize compliance burdens while protecting individual privacy. The Act mandates the implementation of a voluntary prospective reporting system by the Secretary of the Treasury within 180 days of enactment. Employers can report their information, including employer identification numbers and coverage details, through this system. The Secretary of the Treasury will implement a voluntary reporting system for employers to report details such as coverage offered to employees, dependents, spouses, and part-time employees. The Secretary of the Treasury will implement a voluntary reporting system for employers to report details about the coverage offered to employees, including dependents, spouses, and part-time employees, as well as the availability of coverage to full-time employees during the prospective reporting period. The Secretary of the Treasury will implement a voluntary reporting system for employers to report details about coverage offered to employees, including availability to full-time employees, waiting periods, and access to information by Exchanges and the IRS. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act requires processes for secure access to information by Exchanges, the Data Services Hub, and the IRS. It also includes a process for agencies to follow up with employers for additional information related to employee eligibility. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act mandates a system for agencies to follow up with employers to obtain necessary information on employee eligibility for subsidies. Employers using the system must provide updates on coverage changes for participating employees. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act requires agencies to obtain information from employers on employee eligibility for subsidies. Employers must provide timely updates to the Federal Marketplace Data Services Hub regarding any coverage cancellations or significant changes for participating employees. Employers can be exempt from reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code if they meet certain criteria for prospective reporting. Employers must meet reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code by furnishing statements to the IRS and employees who have enrolled in a qualified health plan through the Exchange. Employers can use third parties to complete filing for reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code without affecting their liability. Employers can utilize third parties for filing under the Internal Revenue Code without impacting their liability. Exchanges must notify employers when an employee or dependent enrolls in a qualified health plan. SEC. 4 amends Section 6055(b) of the Internal Revenue Code to allow substitution of name and date of birth for TINs if not collected before 2014 for dependents. Effective date is 60 days after enactment. SEC. 5 pertains to electronic statements. The amendment allows individuals to consent to receive statements electronically from their employer or health insurance provider. Refusal in writing can override electronic delivery. The amendment allows individuals to consent to receive statements electronically regarding health insurance coverage. Refusal in writing can override electronic delivery. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2015. The amendment allows individuals to consent to receive statements electronically regarding health insurance coverage. Refusal in writing can override electronic delivery. SEC. 6. GAO STUDIES. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study evaluating employer notifications by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act regarding full-time employees eligible for tax credits or subsidies. The Comptroller General will study employer notifications by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act regarding full-time employees eligible for tax credits or subsidies, including data elements, notification process, and employer feedback on the information provided. The Comptroller General will study employer notifications by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act regarding full-time employees eligible for tax credits or subsidies, including data elements, notification process, total number of notifications sent, differences between Federal and State-Based Marketplaces, challenges, and recommendations. The Comptroller General will study differences in notification processes between Federal and State-Based Marketplaces, challenges, and recommendations. Additionally, they will assess the establishment of a separate appeals process for employers as required by the Affordable Care Act. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the functionality of the prospective reporting system from January 1, 2017, to December 31, 2017, as required by the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. A report on the study results will be submitted to relevant Senate and House committees within one year of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General will evaluate the prospective reporting system established under section 3 from January 1, 2017, to December 31, 2017. A report on the system's functionality, information accuracy, employer participation, and implementation challenges will be submitted to Senate and House committees by July 1, 2018. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Senate and House committees by July 1, 2018, on the results of the study conducted to evaluate the prospective reporting system established under section 3. SEC. 7. ELIGIBILITY VERIFICATION PROCESS FOR ACA SUBSIDIES. A marketplace can automatically reenroll an individual in a qualified health plan annually, considering eligibility for subsidies and income changes. If the marketplace fails to follow the specified processes, reenrollment limitations apply. The section outlines the process for annual redeterminations of eligibility for subsidies and income changes in marketplace coverage. If a marketplace does not follow the specified processes, reenrollment limitations apply until current income information is provided. The provisions aim to align with guidance issued by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services. The section outlines the process for annual redeterminations of eligibility for subsidies and income changes in marketplace coverage, aligning with guidance from the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services. It ensures that enrollees eligible for automatic reenrollment have their eligibility redetermined. The guidance outlines procedures for annual redeterminations of eligibility for subsidies and income changes in marketplace coverage. It includes requirements for maintaining authorization for disclosure of information, requesting updated income information annually, and providing timely notices to enrollees regarding redeterminations. The guidance outlines procedures for annual redeterminations of eligibility for subsidies and income changes in marketplace coverage, including authorization for disclosure of information, annual income verification, and timely notices to enrollees. The term "marketplace" refers to State Based Exchanges and the Federally Facilitated Exchange.
